Incident.Summary: DUI#23-038Cory Maurice Tabb D.O.B; 10/26/1993 Black/Male was stopped for failure to obey traffic control device (swerving). Tabb was under the influence of Controlled Dangerous Substance and failed SFST. Tabb was arrested for driving under the influence of CDS. 2nd DUI arrest

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText: Defendant: Cory Maurice Tabb Date of Birth:10/23/1996 Date of Arrest: 03/26/2023 Times of Arrest: 0040 Hours DL: MD10272220202 DUI #: 23-038 font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> 2ndDUI font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> ************Related reports: 23-MSP-010789 ********** TRAINING/CERTIFICATES: * Graduated with distinction from the University of Maryland Institute of Advanced Law Enforcement Studies, DUI Institute, Session XIII. I am trained by the Maryland State Police and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to administer standardized field sobriety tests. I am a certified Radar and Lidar operator. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> VEHICLE IN MOTION (PHASE 1) font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> On Sunday, March 26th2023, at approximately 0007 hours, I, Senior Trooper Dugue, (ID# 5832) was working uniformed patrol, operatingmarked MSP unit, A-4. At that time, I was dispatched to westbound Interstate 70, west of Bethany Lane, Ellicott City, Howard County Maryland, to assist Maryland State Trooper, Sergeant Lee, (ID# 2130) of the Maryland State Police Criminal Enforcement Division with a possible intoxicated driver. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> Upon my arrival, I saw a black Acura TL with a Virginia registration, UBC8450 partially in lane number two and the right shoulder of the Interstate 70. I contacted Sgt. Lee who was standing outside behind the black Acura. Sgt. Lee stated that he stopped the driver of the Acura TL because it was moving below the 70 MPH speed limit. Sgt Lee stated the vehicle was moving between 10-15 MPH and created a traffic jam on Interstate 70. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> Please refer to Sgt. Lees supplemental report. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> I contacted the driver of the black Acura. I observed the driver of the Acura to be seated behind the wheel of the vehicle, and he had a cellular telephone in his hands. I asked him to step out of the vehicle. After coming out the vehicle, I saw the driver stumble and started to walk towards lane number two on the highway. I immediately asked him to move out of the traffic and be careful. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> PERSONAL CONTACT (PHASE 2) font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> The driver was identified by his Maryland drivers license as Cory Maurice Tabb, D.O.B: 10/26/1993, African American/Male. Tabb was on his cellular phone talking to an unidentified male. Tabb was unable to provide the subject that was on the phone with him his current location. I took the cellular phone from Tabb and provided the unidentified male that was on the phone our current location. The unidentified subject that was on the phone, stated he was the brother of Tabb and asked me if he could come and pick his brother up. The brother further asked if Tabb was going to get arrested. I advised him the address of the Waterloo Barracks where he is going to be. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> I asked where he was coming from. Tabbs response was very slow. Tabb was not able to answer simple questions. Tabb was not able to stand on his own. Tabbs eyes were glassy and his eyes pupils size were pinpoint. Tabb was not able to understand my questions, and he was unable to answer. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> Iasked Tabb tosubmit to Standardized Field Sobriety Tests, to which he agreed. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> PRE-ARREST SCREENING (PHASE 3)PRE-ARREST SCREENING (PHASE 3) The evaluation was performed on westbound Interstate 70, west of Bethany Lane on the right shoulder. The surface was dryand free from any obvious debris. The weather was clear and approximately 55 degrees. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> Medical Conditions - No Injuries No Medication No font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> HORIZONTAL GAZE NYSTAGMUS(6/6 clues observed) 1.) Lack of Smooth Pursuit Present in both eyes 2.) Distinct and Sustained Nystagmus at Maximum Deviation Present in both eyes 3.) Onset of Nystagmus Prior to 45 Degrees Present in both eyes font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> WALK AND TURN ( 6/8) font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> Tabb was instructed and demonstrated to place his hands flat at his sides and to remain in the position until told to begin. Tabb was advised to take nine (9) steps on a straight line touching heel to toe on every step. Tabb was to keep his hands flat at his side, keep his eyes focused on his feet, and to count every step aloud. On the ninth step, Tabb was explained and demonstrated to keep his lead foot on the line, and to take a series of small steps around with his rear foot to turn completely around. Tabb was again explained and demonstrated the second series of nine (9) steps were to be performed identical to the first series. Tabb was instructed that once he began the test that he was not to stop walking until the test was completed, keep his hands down by his side, look down at his feet, and count each step out loud. I asked if he understood the test, and he shook his head. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> Instructional Stage: 1.) Lost balance- Tabb was unable to keep his balance during the instructional phase. I observed Tabb shortly after he put his right foot in front of his left foot, he lost his balance and put both feet next to each other. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> Walking Stage (1st Nine): 1.) Missed heel to toe by more than an inch on step number 1 and number 2. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> 2.) Missed heel-to-toe- Tabb missed heel to toe on steps number 1 and number 2. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> 3.) Stepped off the Line- Tabb stepped off the line on step number 2. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> 4.) Stop Walking- Tabb stopped walking completely on step number 2 and stopped the Walk and Turn test. 5. Actual Steps Taken- Tabb only took two steps instead of the nine steps he was instructed to do font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> Walking Stage (2nd Nine): Not completed ONE LEG STAND (3/4) Prior to performing the test, I properly explained and demonstrated how the test should be conducted. Tabb was instructed to stand with his heels together and hands down by his sides while the instructions were given and during the test. When instructed to start, he was to raise the foot of his choice off the ground approximately 6 inches. While his leg was raised, he was to keep his leg straight, watch his raised foot, and to count out loud by thousands (one thousand-one, one thousand-two) and to continue the test until told to stop. Tabb was asked if he understood the test and instructions to which he stated, Yes. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> Balance and Count Stage: Seconds 0-10: font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> 1.) Tabb dropped his foot on count 1002. 2.) Tabb swayed to the left. 3.) Tabb lifted both arms away from his body more than 6 inches. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> Seconds 10-20: Foot remained down font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> Seconds 21-30: font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> Foot remained down font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> PRELIMINARYBREATHTEST: Iexplained and offered Tabb a preliminary breath test to which Tabb agreed. The Results were .00 BAC. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> ARREST Based on the following, I had reason to believe Tabb was driving a motor vehicle under the influence dangerous controlled substance: *Eyes glassy font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> *Unable to comprehend and processed simple instructions font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> *Slurred speech font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> *Repeated instructions as needed. *My observed signs of impairment as he performed field sobriety tests. font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> font-variant-ligatures:normal; text-decoration-thickness:initial; text-decoration-style:initial; text-decoration-color:initial" /> At approximately 0040 hours, Tabb was arrested for driving under of Dangerous Controlled substance and transported to the MSP Waterloo Barracks for further processing.The test wasadministered by Sgt. Clark ID#5291. The breath specimen was found to contain an alcohol concentration of.00 grams of alcohol per 210 liters of breath at approximately 0128 hours. After the Breath Test was administered, Sgt. Clark informed the subject the test results. Then, I asked Tabb a Drug Recognition Expert (DRE) will be called to continue the DUI process. At that point, Tabb stated he denied everything, and he did not want to see a DRE personnel. Tabb was charged with driving while impaired. All events occurred in Howard County, Maryland. Case Status: Closed by arrest.

On March 26, 2023, at approximately 0007 hours, I, Sergeant J. Lee ID 2130 of Maryland State Police assigned to the Criminal Enforcement Division, was traveling westbound I-70 west of route 29 in a Maryland State Police unmarked unit CE 164. As I was approaching Bethany Lane, I observed several vehicles that were in front of me and traveling in the same direction coming a sudden slow down. When I came up to the other vehicles, I observed a black Acura bearing Virginia registration UBC 8450 in front of other vehicles traveling approximately 5-10 MPH in a posted speed limit zone of 65 MPH and swerving back and forth from the right shoulder to the far left lane. The other vehicles were unable to get by the Acura due to the swerving and unpredictable movement and after observing the Acuras inability to stay in lane and the slow speed, I initiate a traffic stop by activating my emergency equipment. After a few seconds, the Acura came to a complete and sudden stop in the middle of the roadway, straddling lanes #1 and #2, and when instructed to move the vehicle to the right shoulder, the driver just stared at me and remained stationary in the roadway. I walked up to the passenger side of the vehicle and had to instruct the driver multiple times to turn the steering wheel to the right, at which time he kept turning the steering wheel to the left, and also had to tell the driver to put the transmission into drive, and to give some gas to move the Acura out of the roadway. After multiple attempts, the driver slowly moved the Acura off the roadway and into the right shoulder. While I was in the process of moving my vehicle to the right shoulder and calling out the traffic stop and the circumstances of the traffic stop to Waterloo barrack, the driver got out of the vehicle and begin to stumble towards my vehicle. The driver was asked multiple times to go back inside the vehicle and after completing the radio transmission, I approached the vehicle from the passenger side. Upon contacting the driver, later identified as Cory Maurice Tabb DOB 10/26/1993 by his Maryland Drivers License, I detected a very strong odor of perfume or cologne coming from the vehicle. I looked down at the passenger seat and observed a red tube of an unknown make skin care product. I asked where he was going and why was he traveling at such a low speed. The drivers response and speech were low, slurred, garbled, and hard to understand. I asked the driver where he was going and he said he was heading home. I asked the driver if he lived in Randallstown and he said yes. I advised him that he was actually heading away from Randallstown and he just stared at me without any reaction. After observing the incoherent, low, and slurred speech, I asked him whether he was on medication or have a medical condition I should know about. He advised me that he is not on any medications. Due to the possible impairment, I requested a trooper assigned to Waterloo barrack to respond to my location to assist in the investigation and administer the Standardized Field Sobriety Test (SFST). Trooper First Class DuGue ID 5832 assigned to Waterloo barrack arrived on the scene and resume the investigation and proceeded to administer the SFST. The driver was unable to perform a large portion of the SFST due to the inability to maintain his balance and was subsequently detained for Driving Under the Influence (DUI) by Trooper First Class DuGue. The driver was transported to Maryland State Police Waterloo barrack for processing and disposition. All events occurred in Howard County, Maryland.
